oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Military Pass for the Morey Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small document serving as a military pass allowing Ira Morey, Hannah Morey, two little children, and one son to pass through the Union lines to Louisville, Kentucky, and return within three days. The pass was issued by Brig. Gen. R.S. Granger in Nashville, Tennessee.

Ira Morey served as a Presbyterian minister in several states before arriving in Tennessee in 1849. In 1856, he accepted a position with the Abbe Institute, a school for young ladies in Lebanon, Tenn. In 1858, Rev. Morey moved his family to Franklin, Tennessee. In 1865, Hannah Herrick Morey, Ira's wife, made a futile attempt to obtain the release of their son, James Marsh Morey, from the Union prison on Hart's Island, New York.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil War in the West; Civil War society; United States - History - 1783-1865; United States - History - 1849-1877; United States History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Louisville (Ky.)
Military occupations; Civil Wars; War
